data.Element: Kadcyla contains the active substance trastuzumab emtansine, which is made up of two parts that are linked together:
data.Text: Kadcyla contains the active substance trastuzumab emtansine, which is made up of two parts that are linked together:

data.Element: ·    trastuzumab - a monoclonal antibody that binds selectively to an antigen (a target protein) called human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2). HER2 is found in large amounts on the surface of some cancer cells where it stimulates their growth. When trastuzumab binds to HER2 it can stop the cancer cells growth and cause them to die.
data.Text: trastuzumab - a monoclonal antibody that binds selectively to an antigen (a target protein) called human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2). HER2 is found in large amounts on the surface of some cancer cells where it stimulates their growth. When trastuzumab binds to HER2 it can stop the cancer cells growth and cause them to die.

data.Element: ·    DM1 – an anti-cancer substance that becomes active once Kadcyla enters the cancer cell.
data.Text: DM1 – an anti-cancer substance that becomes active once Kadcyla enters the cancer cell.

data.Element: Kadcyla is used to treat breast cancer in adults when:
data.Text: Kadcyla is used to treat breast cancer in adults when:

data.Element: ·    the cancer cells have many HER2 proteins on them - your doctor will test your cancer cells for this.
data.Text: the cancer cells have many HER2 proteins on them - your doctor will test your cancer cells for this.

data.Element: ·    you have already received the medicine trastuzumab and a medicine known as a taxane.
data.Text: you have already received the medicine trastuzumab and a medicine known as a taxane.

data.Element: ·         the cancer has spread to areas near the breast or to other parts of your body (metastasized)
data.Text: the cancer has spread to areas near the breast or to other parts of your body (metastasized)

data.Element: ·         the cancer has not spread to other parts of the body and treatment is going to be given after surgery (treatment after surgery is called adjuvant therapy).
data.Text: the cancer has not spread to other parts of the body and treatment is going to be given after surgery (treatment after surgery is called adjuvant therapy).

data.Element: Kadcyla can make some existing conditions worse, or cause side effects. See section 4 for more details about what side effects to look out for.
data.Text: Kadcyla can make some existing conditions worse, or cause side effects. See section 4 for more details about what side effects to look out for.

data.Element: Tell your doctor or nurse straight away if you notice any of the following serious side effects while you are given Kadcyla:
Tell your doctor or nurse straight away if you notice any of the following serious side effects while you are given Kadcyla:
data.Text: Tell your doctor or nurse straight away if you notice any of the following serious side effects while you are given Kadcyla:

data.Element: ·    Breathing problems: Kadcyla can cause serious breathing problems such as shortness of breath (either at rest or while performing any type of activity) and cough.  These may be signs of inflammation of your lung, which may be serious, and even fatal. If you develop lung disease your doctor may stop treatment with this medicine.
data.Text: Kadcyla can cause serious breathing problems such as shortness of breath (either at rest or while performing any type of activity) and cough.  These may be signs of inflammation of your lung, which may be serious, and even fatal. If you develop lung disease your doctor may stop treatment with this medicine.

data.Element: ·    Liver problems: Kadcyla can cause inflammation or damage to cells in the liver that can stop the liver from functioning normally. Inflamed or injured liver cells may leak higher than normal amounts of certain substances (liver enzymes) into the bloodstream, resulting in elevated liver enzymes in blood tests. In most cases you will not have any symptoms. Some symptoms could be yellowing of your skin and whites of your eyes (jaundice). Your doctor will check your blood to test your liver function before and regularly during treatment.
data.Text: Kadcyla can cause inflammation or damage to cells in the liver that can stop the liver from functioning normally. Inflamed or injured liver cells may leak higher than normal amounts of certain substances (liver enzymes) into the bloodstream, resulting in elevated liver enzymes in blood tests. In most cases you will not have any symptoms. Some symptoms could be yellowing of your skin and whites of your eyes (jaundice). Your doctor will check your blood to test your liver function before and regularly during treatment.

data.Element: Another rare abnormality that can occur in the liver is a condition known as nodular regenerative hyperplasia (NRH). This abnormality causes the structure of the liver to change and can change how the liver functions. Over time, this may lead to symptoms such as a bloated sensation or swelling of the abdomen due to fluid accumulation or bleeding from abnormal blood vessels in the gullet or rectum.
data.Text: Another rare abnormality that can occur in the liver is a condition known as nodular regenerative hyperplasia (NRH). This abnormality causes the structure of the liver to change and can change how the liver functions. Over time, this may lead to symptoms such as a bloated sensation or swelling of the abdomen due to fluid accumulation or bleeding from abnormal blood vessels in the gullet or rectum.

data.Element: ·    Heart problems: Kadcyla can weaken the heart muscle. When the heart muscle is weak, patients may develop symptoms such as shortness of breath at rest or when sleeping, chest pain, swollen legs or arms, and a sensation of rapid or irregular heartbeats. Your doctor will check your heart function before and regularly during treatment. You should tell your doctor immediately if you notice any of the above symptoms.
data.Text: Kadcyla can weaken the heart muscle. When the heart muscle is weak, patients may develop symptoms such as shortness of breath at rest or when sleeping, chest pain, swollen legs or arms, and a sensation of rapid or irregular heartbeats. Your doctor will check your heart function before and regularly during treatment. You should tell your doctor immediately if you notice any of the above symptoms.

data.Element: ·    Infusion-related reactions or allergic reactions: Kadcyla can cause flushing, shivering fits, fever, trouble breathing, low blood pressure, rapid heartbeat, sudden swelling of your face, tongue, or trouble swallowing during the infusion or after the infusion on the first day of treatment. Your doctor or nurse will check to see whether you are having any of these side effects. If you develop a reaction, they will slow down or stop the infusion and may give you treatment to counteract the side effects. The infusion may be continued after the symptoms improve.
data.Text: : Kadcyla can cause flushing, shivering fits, fever, trouble breathing, low blood pressure, rapid heartbeat, sudden swelling of your face, tongue, or trouble swallowing during the infusion or after the infusion on the first day of treatment. Your doctor or nurse will check to see whether you are having any of these side effects. If you develop a reaction, they will slow down or stop the infusion and may give you treatment to counteract the side effects. The infusion may be continued after the symptoms improve.

data.Element: ·    Bleeding problems: Kadcyla can lower the number of platelets in your blood. Platelets help your blood to clot so you might get unexpected bruising or bleeding (such as nose bleeds, bleeding from gums). Your doctor will check your blood regularly for decreased platelets. You should tell your doctor immediately if you notice any unexpected bruising or bleeding.
data.Text: Kadcyla can lower the number of platelets in your blood. Platelets help your blood to clot so you might get unexpected bruising or bleeding (such as nose bleeds, bleeding from gums). Your doctor will check your blood regularly for decreased platelets. You should tell your doctor immediately if you notice any unexpected bruising or bleeding.

data.Element: ·    Neurological problems: Kadcyla can damage nerves. You may experience tingling, pain, numbness, itching, crawling sensation, pins and needles in your hands and feet. Your doctor will monitor you for signs and symptoms of neurological problems.
data.Text: Kadcyla can damage nerves. You may experience tingling, pain, numbness, itching, crawling sensation, pins and needles in your hands and feet. Your doctor will monitor you for signs and symptoms of neurological problems.

data.Element: 3.       How you are given Kadcyla
Kadcyla will be given to you by a doctor or nurse in a hospital or clinic:
data.Text: Kadcyla will be given to you by a doctor or nurse in a hospital or clinic:

data.Element: ·    It is given by a drip into a vein (intravenous infusion).
data.Text: It is given by a drip into a vein (intravenous infusion).

data.Element: ·    You will be given one infusion every 3 weeks.
data.Text: You will be given one infusion every 3 weeks.

data.Element: How much you will be given

data.Text: How much you will be given

data.Element: ·    You will be given 3.6 mg of Kadcyla for every kilogram of your body weight. Your doctor will calculate the correct dose for you.
data.Text: You will be given 3.6 mg of Kadcyla for every kilogram of your body weight. Your doctor will calculate the correct dose for you.

data.Element: ·    The first infusion will be given to you over 90 minutes. You will be observed by a doctor or nurse while it is being given and for at least 90 minutes following the initial dose, in case you have any side effects.
data.Text: The first infusion will be given to you over 90 minutes. You will be observed by a doctor or nurse while it is being given and for at least 90 minutes following the initial dose, in case you have any side effects.

data.Element: ·    If the first infusion is well tolerated, the infusion on your next visit may be given over 30 minutes. You will be observed by a doctor or nurse while it is being given and for at least 30 minutes following the dose, in case you have any side effects.
data.Text: If the first infusion is well tolerated, the infusion on your next visit may be given over 30 minutes. You will be observed by a doctor or nurse while it is being given and for at least 30 minutes following the dose, in case you have any side effects.

data.Element: ·    The total number of infusions that you will be given depends on how you respond to the treatment and which indication is treated.
data.Text: The total number of infusions that you will be given depends on how you respond to the treatment and which indication is treated.

data.Element: ·    If you experience side effects, your doctor may decide to continue your treatment but lower your dose, delay the next dose or stop the treatment.
data.Text: If you experience side effects, your doctor may decide to continue your treatment but lower your dose, delay the next dose or stop the treatment.

data.Element: Very common (may affect more than 1 in 10 people):

data.Element: ·    Kadcyla may cause inflammation or damage to cells in the liver, resulting in elevated liver enzymes in blood tests. However, in most cases during Kadcyla treatment, liver enzyme levels are elevated mildly and temporarily, do not cause any symptoms, and do not affect liver function.
data.Text: Kadcyla may cause inflammation or damage to cells in the liver, resulting in elevated liver enzymes in blood tests. However, in most cases during Kadcyla treatment, liver enzyme levels are elevated mildly and temporarily, do not cause any symptoms, and do not affect liver function.

data.Text: Common (may affect up to 1 in 10 people):

data.Element: ·    Flushing, shivering fits, fever, trouble breathing, low blood pressure or a rapid heartbeat during the infusion or up to 24 hours after the infusion – these are so-called infusion-related reactions.
data.Text: Flushing, shivering fits, fever, trouble breathing, low blood pressure or a rapid heartbeat during the infusion or up to 24 hours after the infusion – these are so-called infusion-related reactions.

data.Element: ·    Heart problems can occur. Most patients will not have symptoms from the heart problems. If symptoms do occur, cough shortness of breath at rest or when sleeping flat, chest pain and swollen ankles or arms, a sensation of rapid or irregular heartbeats may be observed.
data.Text: Heart problems can occur. Most patients will not have symptoms from the heart problems. If symptoms do occur, cough shortness of breath at rest or when sleeping flat, chest pain and swollen ankles or arms, a sensation of rapid or irregular heartbeats may be observed.

data.Element: 5.       How to store Kadcyla
Kadcyla will be stored by the health professionals at the hospital or clinic.
data.Text: Kadcyla will be stored by the health professionals at the hospital or clinic.

data.Element: ·        Keep this medicine out of the sight and reach of children.
data.Text: Keep this medicine out of the sight and reach of children.

data.Element: ·        Do not use this medicine after the expiry date which is stated on the outer carton and vial after EXP. The expiry date refers to the last day of that month.
data.Text: Do not use this medicine after the expiry date which is stated on the outer carton and vial after EXP. The expiry date refers to the last day of that month.

data.Element: ·        Store in a refrigerator at (2°C ‑ 8°C). Do not freeze.
data.Text: Store in a refrigerator at (2°C ‑ 8°C). Do not freeze.

data.Element: ·        When prepared as a solution for infusion Kadcyla is stable for up to 24 hours at 2°C to 8°C, and must be discarded thereafter.
data.Text: When prepared as a solution for infusion Kadcyla is stable for up to 24 hours at 2°C to 8°C, and must be discarded thereafter.

data.Element: ·        Do not throw away any medicines via wastewater or household waste. Ask your pharmacist how to dispose of medicines you no longer use. These measures will help to protect the environment.

data.Text: Kadcyla 160mg: One vial of powder for concentrate for solution for infusion contains 160 mg of trastuzumab emtansine. After reconstitution one vial of 8 mL solution contains 20 mg/mL of trastuzumab emtansine.

data.Element: ·    The other ingredients are succinic acid, sodium hydroxide (see section 2 under ‘Important information about some of the ingredients of Kadcyla’), sucrose, and polysorbate 20.
data.Text: The other ingredients are succinic acid, sodium hydroxide (see section 2 under ‘Important information about some of the ingredients of Kadcyla’), sucrose, and polysorbate 20.

data.Element: The following information is intended for medical or healthcare professionals only:
The following information is intended for medical or healthcare professionals only:
data.Text: The following information is intended for medical or healthcare professionals only:

data.Element: In order to prevent medicinal product errors it is important to check the vial labels to ensure that the medicinal product being prepared is Kadcyla (trastuzumab emtansine) and not Herceptin (trastuzumab).
data.Text: In order to prevent medicinal product errors it is important to check the vial labels to ensure that the medicinal product being prepared is Kadcyla (trastuzumab emtansine) and not Herceptin (trastuzumab).

data.Element: Kadcyla must be reconstituted and diluted by a healthcare professional and administered as an intravenous infusion. It must not be administered as an intravenous push or bolus.
data.Text: Kadcyla must be reconstituted and diluted by a healthcare professional and administered as an intravenous infusion. It must not be administered as an intravenous push or bolus.

data.Element: Always keep this medicine in the closed original pack at a temperature of 2ºC – 8 ºC in a refrigerator. A vial of Kadcyla reconstituted with water for injections (not supplied) is stable for 24 hours at
data.Text: Always keep this medicine in the closed original pack at a temperature of 2ºC – 8 ºC in a refrigerator. A vial of Kadcyla reconstituted with water for injections (not supplied) is stable for 24 hours at

data.Element: 2ºC – 8 ºC after reconstitution and must not be frozen.
data.Text: 2ºC – 8 ºC after reconstitution and must not be frozen.

data.Element: Appropriate aseptic technique should be used. Appropriate procedures for the preparation of chemotherapeutic medicinal products should be used.
data.Text: Appropriate aseptic technique should be used. Appropriate procedures for the preparation of chemotherapeutic medicinal products should be used.

data.Element: The reconstituted Kadcyla solution should be diluted in polyvinyl chloride (PVC) or latex‑free PVC‑free polyolefin infusion bags.
data.Text: The reconstituted Kadcyla solution should be diluted in polyvinyl chloride (PVC) or latex‑free PVC‑free polyolefin infusion bags.

data.Element: The use of 0.20 or 0.22 micron in-line polyethersulfone (PES) filter is required for the infusion when the concentrate for infusion is diluted with sodium chloride 9 mg/mL (0.9%) solution for infusion.
data.Text: The use of 0.20 or 0.22 micron in-line polyethersulfone (PES) filter is required for the infusion when the concentrate for infusion is diluted with sodium chloride 9 mg/mL (0.9%) solution for infusion.

data.Element: ·      Kadcyla 100mg: using a sterile syringe, slowly inject 5 mL of sterile water for injection into the 100 mg trastuzumab emtansine vial.
data.Text: : using a sterile syringe, slowly inject 5 mL of sterile water for injection into the 100 mg trastuzumab emtansine vial.

data.Element: ·      Kadcyla 160mg: using a sterile syringe, slowly inject 8 mL of sterile water for injection into the 160 mg trastuzumab emtansine vial.
data.Text: : using a sterile syringe, slowly inject 8 mL of sterile water for injection into the 160 mg trastuzumab emtansine vial.

data.Element: ·      Swirl the vial gently until completely dissolved. Do not shake.
data.Text: Swirl the vial gently until completely dissolved. Do not shake.

data.Element: Reconstituted solution should be inspected visually for particulate matter and discolouration prior to administration. The reconstituted solution should be free of visible particulates, clear to slightly opalescent. The colour of the reconstituted solution should be colourless to pale brown. Do not use if reconstituted solution is cloudy or discoloured.
data.Text: Reconstituted solution should be inspected visually for particulate matter and discolouration prior to administration. The reconstituted solution should be free of visible particulates, clear to slightly opalescent. The colour of the reconstituted solution should be colourless to pale brown. Do not use if reconstituted solution is cloudy or discoloured.

data.Element: Discard any unused portion. The reconstituted product contains no preservative and is intended for single use only.
data.Text: Discard any unused portion. The reconstituted product contains no preservative and is intended for single use only.

data.Element: Determine the volume of the reconstituted solution required based on a dose of 3.6 mg trastuzumab emtansine/kg body weight:
data.Text: Determine the volume of the reconstituted solution required based on a dose of 3.6 mg trastuzumab emtansine/kg body weight:

data.Element: Volume (mL) = Total dose to be administered =(body weight (kg) x dose (mg/kg))
20 (mg/mL, concentration of reconstituted solution)

The appropriate amount of solution should be withdrawn from the vial and added to an infusion bag containing 250 mL of sodium chloride 4.5 mg/mL (0.45%) solution for infusion or sodium chloride 9 mg/mL (0.9%) solution for infusion. Glucose (5%) solution should not be used Sodium chloride 4.5 mg/mL (0.45%) solution for infusion may be used without a polyethersulfone (PES) 0.20 or 0.22‑μm in‑line filter. If sodium chloride 9 mg/mL (0.9%) solution for infusion is used for infusion, a 0.20 or 0.22 micron in-line polyethersulfone (PES) filter is required. Once the infusion is prepared it should be administered immediately. Do not freeze or shake the infusion during storage. If diluted aseptically, it may be stored for up to 24 hours at 2°C to 8°C.
data.Text: The appropriate amount of solution should be withdrawn from the vial and added to an infusion bag containing 250 mL of sodium chloride 4.5 mg/mL (0.45%) solution for infusion or sodium chloride 9 mg/mL (0.9%) solution for infusion. Glucose (5%) solution should not be used Sodium chloride 4.5 mg/mL (0.45%) solution for infusion may be used without a polyethersulfone (PES) 0.20 or 0.22‑μm in‑line filter. If sodium chloride 9 mg/mL (0.9%) solution for infusion is used for infusion, a 0.20 or 0.22 micron in-line polyethersulfone (PES) filter is required. Once the infusion is prepared it should be administered immediately. Do not freeze or shake the infusion during storage. If diluted aseptically, it may be stored for up to 24 hours at 2°C to 8°C.
